Well the main thing to consider is that the population is separated 
into s=
pecies. The survival of the fittest, crossover and mutation all 
happen ins=
ide each species. I mean each species does it's own GA in 
order to optimiz=
e its structure. Organisms compete within their own 
niches instead of with=
 the population at large. 
If the growth is too slow, you can raise the mut=
ation probabilities. 
There is always some trial and error involved when yo=
u get to set the 
parameters of the system for the given problem. 
Well I a=
m not familiar with MATLAB NEAT. Try using the C++ or Java 
version instead=
. It may not help much with the general problems of 
deciding the mutation =
rates and the target number of 
species/speciation importance factors, but =
it should be way faster, 
at least the C++ code can be considered faster. 
=

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "psyphiroth.nebu" <psyphiroth.nebu@...=
> 
wrote:
>
> Thanks for your advice, Peter. Could you explain how GA works=
 in 
> NEAT? There is elitism in the program, I thought it would ensure 
th=
e 
> convergence of the algorithm, but it seems there are other 
mechanisms=
 
> that govern the process. Since the elites are preserved, why does 
the =

> process still get stuck? And the networks have barely grown too 
> large=
, with an average number of hidden nodes less than 10 for 
> several hundre=
d generations. I think the algorithm optimizes too 
> slowly, is there some=
 method to change this? I am under 
MATLAB_NEAT, 
> and unfamiliar with pro=
gramming languages other than C and java.
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "petar_chervenski" 
> <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> >
> > Check your specia=
tion parameters and the importance factors for 
> > speciation. Sometimes t=
here are too many species, sometimes there 
> are 
> > too few. The dropoff=
 age is important, too. The overall slow down 
> is 
> > because the networ=
ks grow in size and the simpler species reach 
> their 
> > dropoff age and=
 get killed of by NEAT. This is the explanation 
why 
> > the fitness drops=
, too. You can have an absolute elitism where 
the 
> > best species never =
get killed, no matter how old it is. It seems 
> that 
> > a fitness platea=
u is being reached and NEAT finds it difficult to 
> > optimize in a high-d=
imentional space, the smaller species already 
> > being dead and the more =
complex are left.
> > A possible thing to try is to implement a pruning mec=
hanism. The 
> > phased pruning techniqe by Colin Green (found in SharpNEAT=
) is 
the 
> > one I recommend. This will improve the speed as well as the =

quality 
> > of the overall search. With phased pruning, the lower dimenti=
onal 
> > space is searched better. This helps finding the best starting 
>=
 point 
> > for future generations. 
> > 
> > Peter
>
